entries.title: ğŸ¬ At Our Windows
entries.content:
I am at a window. I am on my phone. I can't stop watching videos of people reacting to the Minneapolis story. It's almost like a movie that doesn't end. So instead of augmenting that endless scroll, here is something LONG and something SHORT:

SÃ¡tÃ¡ntangÃ³ (1994) - BÃ©la Tarr's 7+ hour masterpiece. Hypnotic, glacial, crushing. A film about waiting, dissolution, and the slow dissolution of hope. If you can survive it, you'll understand something about why we're compelled to watch endings we already know. Also available on Kanopy (free with library card).

"Monday" by Billy Collins

The birds are in their trees,
the toast is in the toaster,
and the poets are at their windows.

They are at their windows
in every section of the tangerine of earthâ€”
the Chinese poets looking up at the moon,
the American poets gazing out
at the pink and blue ribbons of sunrise.

The clerks are at their desks,
the miners are down in their mines,
and the poets are looking out their windows
maybe with a cigarette, a cup of tea,
and maybe a flannel shirt or bathrobe is involved.

The proofreaders are playing the ping-pong
game of proofreading,
glancing back and forth from page to page,
the chefs are dicing celery and potatoes,
and the poets are at their windows
because it is their job for which
they are paid nothing every Friday afternoon.

Which window it hardly seems to matter
though many have a favorite,
for there is always something to seeâ€”
a bird grasping a thin branch,
the headlights of a taxi rounding a corner,
those two boys in wool caps angling across the street.

The fishermen bob in their boats,
the linemen climb their round poles,
the barbers wait by their mirrors and chairs,
and the poets continue to stare
at the cracked birdbath or a limb knocked down by the wind.

By now, it should go without saying
that what the oven is to the baker
and the berry-stained blouse to the dry cleaner,
so the window is to the poet.

Just thinkâ€”
before the invention of the window,
the poets would have had to put on a jacket
and a winter hat to go outside
or remain indoors with only a wall to stare at.

And when I say a wall,
I do not mean a wall with striped wallpaper
and a sketch of a cow in a frame.

I mean a cold wall of fieldstones,
the wall of the medieval sonnet,
the original woman's heart of stone,
the stone caught in the throat of her poet-lover.


From The Trouble with Poetry and Other Poems. Read more

entries.title: âš–ï¸ National Security
entries.content:
Almost anything can be justified as a national security concern because the justification is broadly interpreted at an agent's discretion and the reasoning of that suspicion is often adjudicated by human fallible judgment. When a government agent is acting on behalf of a sovereign, culpability is a limited concern until a formidable deterrent (like the prosecution of Derek Chauvin for example) is obvious and threatening.

The mobile phone can be a pervasive threat to a totalitarian government so it needs to be searched and seized without violating the 4th amendment. An, 'examination of information that is resident upon [a] device at the time it is presented for inspection' is deemed necessary.

Fourth Amendment: "The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized."

CBP Border Search Authority

entries.title: ğŸš« Unauthorized Inquiry
entries.content:
It has been interesting to follow the Minneapolis Daycare Fraud story or what the "news" has labeled, "Conservative Social Influencers Give Trump's Team an Amplifier."

Questions regarding the state's role in subsidizing daycare with ineffective oversight are off limits. Questioning normalized outlays is a threatening inquiry and rooted in [insert academic word for popular grievance]. Welfare scrutiny portends a, "symbiotic relationship between the Trump administration and self-described citizen journalists."

The audacity to self-identify is reserved for gender. Credentialism is just another way of saying you need a license to say certain things. You need permission. You can only speak "your" truth in alignment with an approved cause otherwise you are, "in search of politically charged footage and producing viral content that aligns with MAGA policies."

The "news" chooses ad hominem rhetoric instead of investigating the claims made in the video. Internecine rage sells ads so we are directed to the opinions of credentialed individuals who study, "lies, damn lies, and disinformation in the digital world" and authors opining on psychedelics. They are our approved storytellers. They sell advertisements.

entries.title: ğŸ›ï¸ To be GOVERNED
entries.content:
TO BE GOVERNED
To be GOVERNED is to be watched, inspected, spied upon, directed, law-driven, numbered, regulated, enrolled, indoctrinated, preached at, controlled, checked, estimated, valued, censured, commanded, by creatures who have neither the right nor the wisdom nor the virtue to do so. To be GOVERNED is to be at every operation, at every transaction noted, registered, counted, taxed, stamped, measured, numbered, assessed, licensed, authorized, admonished, prevented, forbidden, reformed, corrected, punished. It is, under pretext of public utility, and in the name of the general interest, to be place[d] under contribution, drilled, fleeced, exploited, monopolized, extorted from, squeezed, hoaxed, robbed; then, at the slightest resistance, the first word of complaint, to be repressed, fined, vilified, harassed, hunted down, abused, clubbed, disarmed, bound, choked, imprisoned, judged, condemned, shot, deported, sacrificed, sold, betrayed; and to crown all, mocked, ridiculed, derided, outraged, dishonoured. That is government; that is its justice; that is its morality.
â€” Pierre Proudhon
From: AGAINST THE MACHINE by Paul Kingsnorth

entries.content:

  • Flock Cameras: AI-powered license plate readers everywhere capturing every movement. This is predictive policing infrastructure. I could be flagged as 'suspicious' and detained for a crime I haven't committed. No transparency. No opt-out.
  • Amazon Reviews: Posted a legitimate review of a kid's guitar that couldn't be tuned. Review was flagged and never published (UPDATE 12/31 - Amazon notified that review was published). No explanation. No appeal. Meanwhile, fake 5-star reviews flood the platform.

It barely mentions that Massachusetts refused to cooperate with federal USDA fraud investigations. The author from UC Berkeley then relies on a legal welfare advocate who states that fraud is not "borne out by our experience." This self-righteous Red Guardswoman advocates for SNAP recipients for a living. She states the "broader narratives about fraud by SNAP recipients is completely false." The "broad" fraud narrative will always be false from this Berkeley-broached perspective. Until the lowly taxpayer who is working 3 jobs to pay for someone else to receive $1500/mo. is included in the narrative, it's not journalism, it's Marxist advocacy on behalf of wealthy donors who want you poor, illiterate, and subservient to their revisionist ideology.

entries.title: ğŸ¥ Cal Newport on Why Smart People Quit Social Media

entries.title: âš•ï¸ MAID in America
entries.content:
"If a suffering New Yorker made the difficult choice to die, who am I to stand in their way?" - NY Governor Hochul.

I'm a suffering American and I hope there are people in power who would stand in my way. In melancholic moments I've contemplated or ideated on the end. I get it, mental illness doesn't count. But what does count, is that there are less and less people standing in my way. And there are less and less people standing for my way. Selfishness is pragmatic. Loss is ephemeral. The bad thoughts go away eventually. We prefer to be left alone, free to our own will, autonomous until the end when we lay flat together.

In crisis management we're taught to assess risk so that suicidal ideation is properly managed and walked down. The norm should always be to preserve innocent life; not to hasten death. Democrats smartly retort that it's not about shortening life but shortening death. But what the hell does that even mean? Life is pain. Life can be miserable. And we are all dying at a different pace. The slippery slope is to not speak truthfully about it. To dance around a hard truth is what a politician does. They are vapid; the results of an apathetic electorate. We should come to our senses before even feebly endorsing assisted suicide. We should face it directly and call it what it is. Medical aid in dying (MAID) is anesthetizing a harsh, blunt, and unpleasant end. It is the euphemism of the century. MAID may be practical and convenient. It is also an endorsement of taking innocent life. It also makes me feel empty inside. It makes me contemplate shortening my own death. I'm eventually inconvenient if not already. AI can do my job. But I reject a culture that placates despair. Do you?

entries.title: ğŸ’€ Growth by Negation
entries.content: 'Whatever late capitalism is, it seems to be careening into this embrace of growth by negation. Through that prism, it's hard not to see the advances in something like artificial intelligence less driven by technological breakthroughs as by a society that has, over years, over decades, become normalized to a greater and greater magnitude of both loneliness and theft, such that a sputtering algorithm badly trained on the stolen work of real human beings might be celebrated with a straight face as something approximating humanness. Under this ordering, it is not some corporations increasing capacity for better that drives the extractive world, but everyone else's increasing tolerance for worse.' - Omar El Akkad

Grandpa fixed his car. Dad changed his oil. I can't repair my Tesla nor can I buy an affordable Kei truck that doesn't require long-term financing. I can't upgrade my iPhone hardware ad hoc. My Fitbit stopped working suddenly and Google offered 35% off a newer version. Product obsolescence is planned and amortized so that my inventory loss is their revenue gain. Not upgrading your iPhone is bad for business. Same goes for not financing the house you can't afford, the large vehicle-for-one that sits 80% unused for $760 a month. Smart-anything, subscriptions, IOT dependency, BNPL financing, all requisite reoccurring revenue for ğŸ“ˆ in quarterly earnings presentations. Using their software, you are the product and I'm buying their stock.

entries.title: ğŸ¤ Life Determined
entries.content:
I received notification that Autopilot traded new positions. It sold NVDA than bought it. Stupid (studies show the least active traders beat the busiest by 7%).
AI can't zoom out to provide context. It's current-info-biased. In other words its memory is based on existing code, not past experience. Sure you could code that, prompt that to say, "act like smart investor with memory and don't sell." But this hyper aggressive behavior to buy and sell constantly with new models is a losing strategy. The oracle from Omaha epitomizes investor intelligence. Deep learning, longevity; sagaciousness. Coupled with AI, the individual now can discern with augmented intelligence buts it's not artificial reasoning that supersedes purchasing decisions. The human is not replaceable and is far more interesting than 'just interesting' as some prominent voices have blithely opined. While the luddites overreacted in the past, the AI-emboldened entrepreneur is now well-tooled but amorous. The modern technocrat is mired in their own myopic ideology. I find myself in this camp. Why am I building? What do I believe? It seems so futile. But maybe the despondency is misplaced. Maybe it's not 'tech' or 'no tech' or human v. robot. It's a digestible easy narrative. But maybe it's a false dichotomy. If it's about determinism and whether I can live without free will, then I submit. If all events, including human actions, are causally determined by preceding events and the laws of nature, this means that every event is the inevitable result of what came before, making it impossible to have acted otherwise. Is technological determinism incompatible with free will?
Do I have free will?

entries.title: ğŸ›Œ Sleep
entries.content: If I'm not getting sleep, it's because my circadian rhythm and BRAC (Basic Rest-Activity Cycle) are out of sync or I have something unresolved in my mind. It's not because of my mattress. Adhering to cycles and physical exhaustion from having woken up early, help my body know when to sleep and when to wake up. The solution for me so far? Waking up early and exercising to maintain a consistent sleep cycle. I refuse to spend $5,000 on a smart mattress pad.

entries.title: ğŸ¥ The Hidden Costs of Healthcare
entries.content: Our healthcare system is broken, with insurance creating perverse incentives that inflate costs. A simple blood test panel costs $255 privately but $964 through insurance. The system discourages price shopping as patients only see minimal copays, while doctors are incentivized to order unnecessary tests. Even 'preventive care' often feels like a data collection scheme, with insurance companies offering small rewards for personal health data. The solution? More transparency and questioning whether each test or prescription is truly necessary. Read more

This is difficult. Live and think like a hunter gatherer? Okay, but I'm depressed, broke, and despondent. Take glucagon-like peptides (GLP-1)? Now we're talking ğŸ’°. Ask a doctor and the capital markets how they can make money off my fat ass. No exploitable free cash flow in a healthy neanderthal.

entries.title: ğŸšï¸ Rent Control Market Distortions
entries.content: NYT states that 1M rent-controlled landlords net operating income was up 12.1% and that they're, 'actually doing pretty well.' Big thing missing. Just a major fact. Missing. Landlords costs are down because they're not investing in their properties. They aren't spending or are disclosing the smallest costs to justify whatever increases they can get under state control. State intervention will always have adverse market incentives. Remove the state and a Fair Market Rent and a Free Market system will fascilitate price discovery. Landlords will invest and tenants will get better deals. More compliance costs, more state intervention, and you get HIGHER PRICES.

entries.content: I want a Defender so I can drive on top of dunes and up streams to waterfalls and up steps to Tudor homes.

entries.title: ğŸŒ† Nob Hill
entries.content:
Asian Man Black shoes
Rolls Royce Dusty top
Long shadows on a Friday night bench
An Acura parked long term. A tucked ticket.
Clipping heals to date night.
Gas engines purring from stop signs.
Wandering elderly man in sneakers, jeans, and a sweatshirt.
A crew, 'for me to be happy in the cityâ€¦'
Sitting still is not easy.
The world passes you by and it's completely indifferent.
The sun feels nice and the cable cars creak; comfort in cacophony and cacophony in comfort.
A weird word. A weird world.
